channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Judge Rejects Annulment of Ex-Dictator’s Guatemala Trial
item.description: The legal confusion cast into relief the polarized emotions that have been raised by a month of testimony about the bloodiest chapter in the country’s long civil war.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Efraín Ríos Montt, in glasses, after a hearing on Friday during his trial on genocide charges in Guatemala City. A judge is trying to have the case retried.

item.title: Spectator Interrupt’s Nicolás Maduro During Inaugural Address
item.description: A man pushed Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s new president, away from the microphone as he delivered his inaugural address.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A red-jacketed man pushed Nicolás Maduro, center right, away from the microphone as he delivered his inaugural address in Caracas on Friday.

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on the Boston Blasts
item.description: The Lede is following the aftermath of Monday’s deadly explosions at the Boston Marathon, which killed three and injured more than 170 on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Chris Young/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Maret Tsarnaeva, an aunt of the two suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Using the Law to Crack the Glass Ceiling
item.description: Much of Europe relies on voluntary action by companies to get more women into boardrooms. But with the number of women executives continuing to lag, there is growing pressure for legislation. Join the conversation: Do you think governments should pass laws stipulating how many women are on a corporation’s board?
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Americans Learn of Chechnya
item.description: Marcus Mabry, Rendezvous’s editor, speaks to Clifford J. Levy, the former Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times, about the Chechen origins of the suspected Boston Marathon bombers,Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Ode to Pasta, and to the Pluck of the Italian Family Business
item.description: A show this week to honor the pasta maker Pietro Barilla, who would have turned 100 on Tuesday, was a feel-good moment for a country whose businesses are feeling bad.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: World Briefing : Italian Lawmakers Fail a 4th Time to Elect a President
item.description: The center-left candidate, former Prime Minister Romano Prodi, was unable to muster enough support in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Top U.N. Rights Official Denounces Iraqi Executions
item.description: The official, Navi Pillay, accused the Baghdad government of killing prisoners “like animals in a slaughterhouse.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Competition Designed to Spread Basic Technologies
item.description: The World Bank is organizing a competition to find solutions that address access to technology in developing countries.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER
item.media:description: A boy at a school in Dakar, Senegal, reports the condition of toilets with a text-messaging tool.

item.title: Assailants Gun Down Syrian Official
item.description: A squad of assailants shot to death a government official in a gangland-style killing as he dined in the upscale Mezzeh district of the Syrian capital, residents and activists said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Syria Envoy Offers Grim View of Conflict to U.N.
item.description: Lakhdar Brahimi, the special envoy representing the United Nations and the Arab League, said that Damascus was uncooperative in negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: British Police Arrest Entertainer in Abuse Inquiry
item.description: The British media identified Rolf Harris, a singer and artist, as the newest high-profile arrest after the Jimmy Savile affair.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Rape of 5-Year-Old Sparks Protest in India’s Capital
item.description: The reported rape of a 5-year-old girl by a male neighbor in the Indian capital, New Delhi, triggered a protest march by her relatives and political activists.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: A 5-year-old girl was transferred to another hospital in New Delhi as hundreds of people protested the reported rape.

item.title: Toyota Will Make Lexus ES 350 in Kentucky
item.description: The automaker’s move is partly an effort to protect itself from currency swings that have affected its profit in recent years.
item.category: Lexus Division of Toyota Motor Corp
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Serbia and Kosovo Reach Milestone Deal
item.description: The accord over municipalities in Kosovo’s Serb-majority north paves the way for Kosovo and Serbia to pursue membership in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: From left: Prime Minister Ivica Dacic of Serbia, Catherine Ashton, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, and Prime Minister Hashim Thaci of Kosovo.

item.title: African Islamists Free French Captives
item.description: A French family held hostage for two months by Islamist militants in West Africa has been released, French and Cameroonian officials announced on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: The adult family members, who were held hostage in West Africa, at the French embassy in Yaounde, Cameroon, on Friday.

item.title: Serbia, Kosovo Reach Tentative Deal on Relations
item.description: The prime ministers of Serbia and Kosovo reached a tentative deal to normalize relations between the Balkan neighbors and end years of acrimony.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Way of the World: Banker Steps Into the Role of Superhero
item.description: In the stagnant world economy today, we have designated central bankers as our superheroes, and we are relying on their magical monetary powers to restart global growth.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: Musharraf Is Arrested and Held in Pakistan
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, a former military leader in Pakistan, was arrested and moved into police custody — an unprecedented move in a country where the military has held sway for decades.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: An election banner showing Pervez Musharraf is used as a curtain on the outskirts of Islamabad.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 19
item.description: The birthday of Lord Ram being celebrated in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A statue of Hindu god Hanuman being carried for a procession in New Delhi, on the occasion of Rama Navami, the birthday of Lord Ram.

item.title: Even Violent Drug Cartels Fear God
item.description: In a Mexican prison run by the country’s most feared criminal syndicate, a Brooklyn-born priest struggles to save the most hardened souls.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Dominic Bracco II/Prime, for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Robert Coogan waits to exit the prison in Saltillo, Mexico.

item.title: U.S.: Speculation About Chechen Origins
item.description: The Times’s Clifford J. Levy discusses what is known about the backgrounds of the Boston bombing suspects.

item.title: Scotland Yard Bolsters Police Presence at London Marathon
item.description: The deployment of hundreds of additional officers is designed to reassure contestants and spectators after the Boston attacks.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The United States and Guns
item.description: The reporter Michael Luo tells Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, that the Newtown shooting did change something in America, despite the defeat of gun control measures.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 19
item.description: The F.B.I. releases pictures of two suspects in the Boston bombings; a new Jewish museum in Warsaw; Germany approves the Cyprus bailout; Anna Netrebko in “Eugene Onegin” ; and the impact of hits in rugby.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Gretchen Ertl for The New York Times
